2:T6aa,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"FAQPage","mainEntity":[{"@type":"Question","name":"Do Chileans need a visa for Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"No visa required for 90 days. For longer stays, apply for Mercosur associate residency, which gives you 2 years with work rights."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I use my Chilean ID card (cÃ©dula) to enter?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"At land borders, yes. The cÃ©dula works for Mercosur freedom of movement at border crossings."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"How is the Chilean community in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Large and well-established, especially in Buenos Aires and Mendoza. There's a strong presence of Chilean professionals, students, and families."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Will my Chilean Spanish be understood?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, though Chilean Spanish (with its unique slang and fast pace) might take some getting used to for Argentines. The reverse is also true - you'll adjust to Argentine Spanish quickly."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Is it true that Argentina is cheaper than Chile?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, significantly. Buenos Aires is 30-40% cheaper than Santiago, especially for rent, dining out, and services. This is a major draw for Chileans."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I work for a Chilean company while living in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes, many Chileans do exactly this.
